feed.title: untitled
feed.subtitle: a mix of basketball, tech, and other things that cross my mind

entry.title: Daily: new app in town
entry.content:
I had a fun time finding some really streets to climb in SF. Without tourists, I even got to go up the wiggly Lombard St. Afterwards I counted the cogs on my cassette and realized it‚Äôs an 11-30, which means I still have some room to get gears better for climbing. I never anticipate really ever having to use that though, so I probably won‚Äôt do it.

Twitter

There‚Äôs a new social app that‚Äôs all the rage- Clubhouse.

Here's your first look at Clubhouse, the app every VC is talking about https://t.co/xIdqnz8DS8

— joshconstine (@JoshConstine) April 19, 2020

It‚Äôs a spontaneuous audio group chat app, and twitter was just bunch of clubhouse takes today.

Articles

Marc is back! Must read

Podcasts

Caught up on a few Stratechery daily updates. Bet the Process about the traits behind successful gamblers / advantage players.

Videos

Davie504 is a riot.

Engineering!
entry.summary: I had a fun time finding some really streets to climb in SF. Without tourists, I even got to go up the wiggly Lombard St. Afterwards I counted the cogs on my cassette and realized it‚Äôs an 11-30, which means I still have some room to get gears better for climbing. I never anticipate really ever having to use that though, so I probably won‚Äôt do it.

entry.title: Daily: the days blend together
entry.content:
I‚Äôm on a lighter week of running / biking this week after three pretty tough weeks. I‚Äôll actually still try to up my run mileage after feeling really good running pretty easy on Monday. I did a steady 5mi @ 7:00 pace today and it never felt too fast, so I was pretty pleased by that. I‚Äôm still wary of doing too much faster running, so will probably just chill below 8:00 for the rest of my miles this week.

I‚Äôm happy about being productive today, and it‚Äôs a really good feeling to be in flow state, just letting irrelevant shit not use up any brain cycles. I wonder if consistency around sleeping / waking up can help with achieving sustained productivity / flow state across days instead of just within days. Everything is just blending together anyways. The internet has become reality. [insert something something Baudrillardian hyperreality]

Twitter

Adding to the COVID cocaphony again, but this was cool.

pretty cool that when you publish the code to your ideas/charts/models, people can easily test new ideas on top of it! https://t.co/r1UOw9Ki91

— Canzhi (@canzhiye) April 15, 2020

Kostya was able to test using deaths data instead of cases data on this kind of novel take trying to estimate real-time rate of transmission by just changing a few lines of code because OP made it public. So much easier to trust data analysis that is reproduceable too.

Articles

Really sad Wired article about Lee Holloway and the effects of FTD on not only him, but his family, friends, and coworkers.

Podcasts

good overview of ‚Äúadvanced‚Äù stats in soccer. I‚Äôve been dabbling in doing some predictive modeling for soccer after I stumbled upon some event data and this was an easy to listen to overview of the more popular parts (not cutting edge) of soccer analytics.

Videos

I got weird recs lol
entry.summary: I‚Äôm on a lighter week of running / biking this week after three pretty tough weeks. I‚Äôll actually still try to up my run mileage after feeling really good running pretty easy on Monday. I did a steady 5mi @ 7:00 pace today and it never felt too fast, so I was pretty pleased by that. I‚Äôm still wary of doing too much faster running, so will probably just chill below 8:00 for the rest of my miles this week.

entry.title: Daily: Last few days
entry.content:
Rohan and I agreed we‚Äôd be writing 3 times / week. Putting something here everyday seems to induce me to produce just like super low quality stuff (see 3/25 lol).

This week was my biggest biking week ever - 178 miles and over 12 hours in the saddle. If I do my long run tomorrow (pending how my achilles feel), I‚Äôll have completed 15 hours of cardio this week. If all goes well, it‚Äôd be fun to race once that‚Äôs a thing again and see the progress. Next week will be a lighter week to make sure I‚Äôm not getting too fatigued after three pretty big weeks by my standards.

Twitter

üíØ
weirdest stuff i saw were these effusive articles about how like Vietnam didn‚Äôt have covid TWO WEEKS ago. they‚Äôre on lockdown now. people writing this stuff & people sharing on here are just trying to score points... https://t.co/JGYv6dStq8

— canzhi is at home right now (@canzhiye) April 8, 2020

I want to expand on this take a little bit. It‚Äôs never been clearer to me that the media has no interest in searching for truth. They just want to feed the masses; produce lowest common denominator content. A great example of this is the growing genre of ‚Äúwhat we can learn from how X handled coronavirus.‚Äù We‚Äôre so early in understanding anything about covid, the context behind every country is so different, and the quality of data presented as evidence in these articles is so poor.

These inter-country comparisons really stoke the flames of the incessant online culture wars. People will conflate properties of a country‚Äôs political system with how well they‚Äôve allegedly handled coronavirus, and suggest that if the US did a bunch of completely unrelated political things, then coronavirus would be less severe here too. This stuff is either intentionally intellectually dishonest‚Ä¶ or people‚Äôs brains are completely broken- they‚Äôre just out here building their narratives, their personal brands.

Articles

covid effects where you might not immediately think about

old thing by @vgr but came across for the first time via twitter recently

Podcasts

I absolutely need to stop listening to news podcasts. It‚Äôs filling my brain with noise‚Ä¶ basically static.

Videos

I don‚Äôt even like baseball, but any content that Jon Bois produces, I will gladly consume. Voraciously. His new (ongoing) series on the Seattle Mariners is pretty good (ha ha).

He‚Äôs probably one of the most underrated geniuses of this century. His 5-part MMA documentary examines the relationship between labor, fighting, and our postmodern condition. It has <1M views. Dumb clickbait shit by Buzzfeed has tens of millions of views. Bullshit. People lack taste.

Misc

I don‚Äôt really like following national politics, but Bernie dropping out did make me spend a few brain cycles here. After being the favorite post Iowa / New Hampshire / Nevada, he somehow still failed to be recognized as a legit mainstream candidate. The Weeds did a good episode about what‚Äôs next and what to take away from his candidacy. If his most vocal supporters are representative at all of his wider support, I‚Äôm becoming increasingly concerned that they‚Äôll either sit out the election or vote for Trump. In fact, a second term for Trump definitely adds more to the narrative that running a moderate candidate doesn‚Äôt work (Hillary 2016, Biden 2020), whether that‚Äôs actually true or not. It almost makes more sense for the hardcore Bernie supporters to just vote for Trump. Anyway, I don‚Äôt really add anything to the politics discourse, so I will stop here.

I watched a Zwift race for the first time this week! Is this esports? The race is somewhat gamified through powerups, but ultimately, the competitors still have to do the thing they‚Äôd do for the actual sport. So maybe not really an esport. Interested in seeing how this evolves!
entry.summary: Rohan and I agreed we‚Äôd be writing 3 times / week. Putting something here everyday seems to induce me to produce just like super low quality stuff (see 3/25 lol).

entry.title: Daily: Empty brain
entry.content:
My brain has been feeling a bit empty the past week.

I started doing some freelance iOS work. It‚Äôs very nostalgic, given that making apps was how I got started with programming‚Ä¶back in 2009/2010!!! Time really goes too fast.

Without sports, my content consumption patterns have changed a lot. I feel like I‚Äôm looking at a lot more normie stuff than I used to. I guess that‚Äôs what happens when the thing I actually know a lot about gets taken from me. Maybe it‚Äôs time to get deep into something else?

I have an anon twitter account where I kind of just stream some of my random thoughts to. I like the idea of being anon because my ideas there get judged more for their quality than for who they‚Äôre tweeted by. It‚Äôs also just an outlet for bursts of kind of hot takes that I don‚Äôt want to attach my name to. Maybe that‚Äôs problematic lol
entry.summary: My brain has been feeling a bit empty the past week.

entry.title: Daily: April is the cruelest month, or something

link.title: Daily: April is the cruelest month, or something

entry.content:
Work

I‚Äôm doing some contracting for a friend. Cool to be doing iOS work again. Kind of back to my roots. I can‚Äôt believe it‚Äôs been over 10 years since I first downloaded Xcode and learned to code. Now I get to do much cooler stuff of course :)

Workout

I got new running shoes, or really they‚Äôre just a new pair of the old shoes I had. Especially in these times, I‚Äôll opt for exploit over explore.

Reading

Left as an exercise for the reader
entry.summary: Work I‚Äôm doing some contracting for a friend. Cool to be doing iOS work again. Kind of back to my roots. I can‚Äôt believe it‚Äôs been over 10 years since I first downloaded Xcode and learned to code. Now I get to do much cooler stuff of course :)

entry.title: Daily: It‚Äôs been a few days

link.title: Daily: It's been a few days

entry.content:
Consuming calories

I‚Äôve gotten to cook a lot more, which is usually tons of fun, but also so easy for me to feel like I‚Äôm running out of ideas with a slightly limited set of ingredients.

I‚Äôve made normal boring stuff like scrambled eggs, pb sandwiches, pasta, burgers, etc

Here‚Äôs some of the (weirder) stuff I‚Äôve taken pics of:

Sous vide chicken thighs in some buns‚Ä¶no veggies, so threw some carrots on it.

This was okay, but crazy spicy.

what the fuck did i just make pic.twitter.com/aWgyjWpCKs

— canzhi is at home right now (@canzhiye) March 28, 2020

I usually hate instant coffee, but I went and grabbed some to make this. Was too much effort to whip it up for a mediocre tasting drink.

made the dalgona coffee thing pic.twitter.com/LN2TGzCocg

— canzhi is at home right now (@canzhiye) March 29, 2020

Sous vide chicken thighs, with Indian-ish flavors (turmeric, ginger, cumin, salt, pepper). I also don‚Äôt know why these images aren‚Äôt rotated properly.

Braised red cabbage with onions and apples. Didn‚Äôt have any carbs, so I threw it in some tortillas.

Burning calories

I did 130 miles on the bike and 19 miles on my feet last week ‚Äì probably my biggest week of cardio work in a long time, so I was pretty worn out by Sunday. Silver lining of this corona stuff is I‚Äôll hopefully come out of this in top cardio shape, and maybe I‚Äôll do a couple races. I‚Äôve been running way slower (intentionally) than ever before, but I‚Äôm hoping it pays off by keeping me free of weird pains and aches that I‚Äôve gotten before.

entry.title: Daily: Real-world data and some ranting

link.title: Daily: Real-world data and some ranting

entry.content:
People love to read too much into dumb headlines. So many people shared the ‚ÄúUS surpasses Italy in confirmed coronaviruses cases‚Äù news today. Guess what? It‚Äôs fucking meaningless! We could‚Äôve looked at the growth rate some days ago and known this was going to happen. Additionally, once again, confirmed cases aren‚Äôt a great metric (more below). If I‚Äôm going to spend brain cycles on coronavirus, I want to think critically, go beneath the surface, and explore data myself‚Ä¶ OR make memes. Not share these normie-ass articles.

The second-order effects of these braindead articles are odd. I‚Äôve even seen it lead to some of my Facebook friends (who are a lost cause by now ‚Äì they still think this is nothing more than the flu) to proclaim that ‚ÄúWELL ACTUALLY Italy still has more cases per capita.‚Äù Wow they must be so smart to know how to divide a number by the population of a country. Many of these people like to talk about how the media is incentivized to spin stories to attract clicks / views, and how because of this we can‚Äôt trust the media. In some ways, I share their disdain‚Ä¶

I started poking around at some of the different sources of covid related out there. covidtracking.com is really doing a lot of the thankless work around cleaning data from many different sources ‚Äì very much appreciated. I have a public notebook with some code here: https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1qr6G1dxj9I1OlAdxqlZECFQdqfV9RDps

I‚Äôm trying to find the right questions to ask ‚Äì they should be answerable from available data, help people get a clearer view of what is actually going on, and not already discussed ad naseum. I‚Äôm hesitant to do any forecasting because of lack of domain knowledge, and I certainly don‚Äôt want to add more noise to an already incredibly exhausting topic.

Testing vs Confirmed cases

There was a good thread by a buddy on the high correlation between number of tests and confirmed cases.

FYI: the growth in positive test results per @COVID19Tracking data maps almost 1:1 with the growth in tests performed : R^2 of 0.97. In other words, reporting new and daily case counts is really just reporting on the ramp up in testing capability. @DanRosenheck @Noahpinion pic.twitter.com/T0aZBmVZLm

— Kostya Medvedovsky (@kmedved) March 27, 2020

I learned from one of the replies that finding R^2 between two time series can lead to spurious correlations though. Curious to see the follow up on this. Or I guess I could do the work myself here‚Ä¶

Random testing

so reading from the source, it's a bit nuanced.

5564 tests on "likely" people (prob similar criteria to US). 685 positive. (12%)

6163 tests on the general population. 52 positive. (0.8%)https://t.co/Koeyjk5loP

— canzhi is at home right now (@canzhiye) March 27, 2020

To my knowledge, Iceland is the only country thus far to do random testing of the general population. They lead the world in tests per 1000 at roughly 30. For comparison, the two highest US states are NY and WA, at 7 and 6 respectively. We have data on Iceland‚Äôs randomized tests for 3/20, 3/23, and 3/25 so maybe we can do something with this data. Simple back of the envelope calculation tells us that means there are 2.5M people in the US with the virus if we extrapolate using Iceland‚Äôs rate. There‚Äôs so many other variables that could render the previous sentence completely inccorect that I almost didn‚Äôt want to include it here. Will need to think more about how to best use this data.

More on data

Speaking of data, the NYT released their county-level coronavirus data. I felt kind of misled by their article though.

this is excellent! can you also release this data? pic.twitter.com/SKwAJo8XCT

— canzhi is at home right now (@canzhiye) March 27, 2020

Not that county-level data isn‚Äôt useful, but seems like getting information about those who actually got the virus would be very useful, or at the very least, interesting to analyze. Perhaps there is county-level demographic and health data that is easily accessible that I could merge with the NYT data‚Ä¶ If I remember to go look for it and find it, I‚Äôll add it to the notebook.

In looking at the testing data from covidtracking.com more closely (with Kostya), I found that the quality was not ideal. There were quite a few days where NY just didn‚Äôt report any negative cases‚Ä¶ Such is real-world data, I guess. With sports, the data quality is usually much higher. When I‚Äôm modeling sports, I feel pretty confident that whatever data is captured is done in a relatively consistent way across games and seasons (still not perfect). It really is a great playground.

Masks

I‚Äôve heard conflicting information about the efficacy of masks. The WHO dismisses their usefulness as a protective measure for healthy people, and Michael Osterholm (epidemiologist expert) echoed it on Joe Rogan‚Äôs podcast a couple weeks ago. However, I have also seen a document compiling a list of studies that claim that masks are helpful! There‚Äôs just so much stuff on the internet that you will get exactly what you search for.

I don‚Äôt know what to believe. Now that the level of seriousness has been ratcheted up, I feel much more aware of how easily misinformation or even half-truths can be spread on social media. This doesn‚Äôt feel like the malicious fake news campaigns from the 2016 election, but more an overconfidence in something where the truth is not known. If anyone asks me if masks are effective, I‚Äôll fall back to ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù but if I have to go to the grocery store, I‚Äôll take the Pascal‚Äôs wager approach.
entry.summary: People love to read too much into dumb headlines. So many people shared the ‚ÄúUS surpasses Italy in confirmed coronaviruses cases‚Äù news today. Guess what? It‚Äôs fucking meaningless! We could‚Äôve looked at the growth rate some days ago and known this was going to happen. Additionally, once again, confirmed cases aren‚Äôt a great metric (more below). If I‚Äôm going to spend brain cycles on coronavirus, I want to think critically, go beneath the surface, and explore data myself‚Ä¶ OR make memes. Not share these normie-ass articles.

entry.title: Daily: slow
entry.content:
Ran in the rain today. Did a couple miles a little faster in the middle of the run. Lower calves don‚Äôt feel great, so rest of week of running will be much easier / slower.

Wrote some code for a little project that will hopefully launch this weekend :)

Twitter

Keith vs Zach lol some of it here

I don‚Äôt know anything here, so abstaining from commentary.

Podcasts

The Weeds on what to do with industry in times like these. Some comparisons to Ford, factories, etc producing necessary things in WWII. It‚Äôs like a car crash - I can‚Äôt not pay attention.

Misc

Still looking to take a deeper dive into the covid data. Lack of domain knowledge caveat applies here, but I think I have a few ideas on how I can add something to the discussion without being absolutely destroyed like @aginnt. Main thing I want to look at is incorporating testing and demographic data to contextualize the confirmed cases graphs I see everywhere.

The situation around KAT‚Äôs mom is really sad. Very brave of him to get in front of a camera and deliver this message.

WE CAN BEAT THIS, BUT THIS IS SERIOUS AND WE NEED TO TAKE EVERY PRECAUTIONS. https://t.co/zxMqVB9AWk via @YouTube

— Karl-Anthony Towns (@KarlTowns) March 25, 2020
entry.summary: Ran in the rain today. Did a couple miles a little faster in the middle of the run. Lower calves don‚Äôt feel great, so rest of week of running will be much easier / slower.

entry.title: Daily: untitled
entry.content:
Does the wildlife come out when humans retreat?

Twitter

Don‚Äôt remember.

Articles

Read some stuff about multi-armed bandits.

Podcasts

Bet the Process episode recorded at Sloan came out today. Interviews with Ted Knutson and Jeff Yass were both insightful. Knutson was pretty negative about the prospects of a thriving regulated & legalized betting market in the US. Or more specifically it‚Äôd only be for recreational bettors. Yass talked about how at SIG they teach all the new traders to play poker first to learn about variance and process-oriented decision making. I think that‚Äôs really cool! I‚Äôm not good at poker, but those aspects of the game appeal to me as well. Playing games with a mix of luck and skill is way more fun than a game like chess, which is a perfect information all skill game. Actually, not only is it way more fun, it is a much more realistic representation of the real world where we never have perfect information.

Videos

More multi-armed bandit stuff. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kY-BCNHd_dM

Misc

Spent some time on Indiehackers today. Exploring ideas to hack on!
entry.summary: Does the wildlife come out when humans retreat?
